Graphical abstract The fundamentals, synthesis and modification strategies of the transition metal carbonates as the anode materials for rechargeable Lithium batteries are discussed and summarized in detail. Even though transition metal carbonates (TMCs, TM = Fe, Mn, Co, Ni etc.), show high theoretical capacities, rich reserves and environmental friendliness as anodes for lithium-ion batteries (LIBs), they suffer from sluggish electronic/ionic conductivities and huge volume variation, which severely deteriorate the rate capacities and cycling performances. Understanding the intrinsic reaction mechanism and further developing ideal TMC-based anode with high specific capacity, excellent rate capabilities, and long-term cycling stability are critical for the practical application of TMCs. In this review, we firstly focus on the fundamental electrochemical energy-storage mechanisms of TMCs, in terms of conversion-reaction process, pseudocapacitance-type charge storage, valence change for charge storage and catalytic conversion mechanisms. Based on the reaction mechanisms, various modification strategies to improve the electrochemical performance of TMCs are summarized, covering: (i) micro-nano structural engineering, in which the influence factors on the morphology are discussed, and multiple architectures are listed; (ii) elemental doping, in which the intrinsic mechanisms of metal/nonmetal elements doping on the electrochemical performance are deeply explored; (iii) multifunctional compositing strategies, in which the specific affections on structure, electronic conductivity and chemo-mechanical stability are summarized. Finally, the key challenges and opportunities to develop high-performance TMCs are discussed and some solutions are also proposed. This timely review sheds light on the path towards achieving cost-effective and safe LIBs with high energy density and long cycling life using TMCs-based anode materials. Keywords Transition metal carbonates Electrochemical reaction mechanism Micro-nano structure engineering Elemental doping Multifunctional compositing 1 Introduction Since the successful commercialization in 1990s, the researches about lithium-ions batteries (LIBs) have sprung up, and the practical applications of LIBs in our daily life, such as the hybrid electric vehicles (HEVs), communication devices and stationary grid storage, are booming, owing to high energy density, high power density, long service time and acceptable safety of LIBs. Although the scientific groups recently devote more and more attentions on other metal-ions batteries, such as sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) and potassium-ion batteries (PIBs), to avoid excessive consumption and cost-ascending of Li resource, it is undeniable that the electrochemical energy storage equipment markets will still be dominated by LIBs in decades, owing to higher energy density and maturity of manufacturing technologies of LIBs [1–3]. LIBs are structurally comprised of functional parts of cathodes, anodes, separator, and electrolyte. For the cathode, TiS2 was first used as the cathode material for LIBs, and the full cell assembled with TiS2 cathode and Li metal anode shows an energy density of 130 Wh kg−1, which has been eliminated due to severe security problem. Subsequently, transitional metal oxides including layered LiCoO2 (ca. 274 mAh g−1), olive LiFePO4 (ca. 150 mAh g−1), layer-structured LiNi1− x − y Co x Mn y O2 (0 < x, y < 1, ca. 160 mAh g−1), and spinel LiMn2O4 (ca. 120 mAh g−1) etc., were applied as LIBs cathodes, further enriching the cathode family [4–7]. Meanwhile, the electrolytes evolved from LiPF6 solution in single solvent (ethylene carbonate (EC), diethyl carbonate (DEC), and dimethyl carbonate (DMC), dimethoxyethane (DME) etc.), to combined solvents and recently to the solid electrolyte including ceramic and polymer, aiming to enhance the security and stability of LIBs [8–10]. During the incubation period of LIBs, its commercialization process was blocked for a long time by lacking proper anode materials. In the 1990s, Sony Co. reported the first-generation commercial LIBs comprising of petroleum coke as anode and LiCoO2 as cathode, which is a milestone in the history of LIBs [10]. Nowadays, graphite-type carbon has been the dominant anode material for commercial LIBs after 30 years’ development [11–13]. LIBs with graphite as the anode can provide a theoretical energy density of nearly 300 Wh kg−1 in practice. However, with the outbreak of HEVs, EVs and portable electrical devices, higher energy density (350–500 Wh kg−1) is a desirable task, which requires higher specific capacity of electrode materials. In addition, the lithiation/delithiation potential of graphite approaching 0 V (vs. Li/Li+) is too low to avoid the generation of lithium dendrite, resulting in severe safety concerns [14,15]. All of these factors of commercial LIBs cannot fulfill the stringent requirements of the advanced fields, and consequently, greatly hamper the development of LIBs [16]. Therefore, exploration of high-performance anode materials with large specific capacity and high safety is extremely urgent. Numerous new materials have been developed as advanced anode materials of LIBs, including the intercalation/deintercalation-type anodes [17,18], alloying/dealloying-type anodes of Si, Ge, Sb, and their corresponding oxides, etc. [19,20], and conversion-type transition metal compounds (MaXb, M = Fe, Co, Mn, Ni, etc.; X = O, S, Se, N, CO3, etc.), including transition metal oxides (TMOs) [21,22], transition metal chalcogenides (TMSs) [23,24], transition metal nitrides (TMNs) [25,26] and transition metal carbonates (TMCs). Among these anodes, TMCs recently have attracted great attentions due to their unexpected high lithium storage capacity, intrinsically security, abundant reserves, and low cost [27,28]. For a long time, TMCs had been used as the precursor to synthesize other transition metal compounds mainly including TMOs. Until 2007, Aragón et al. applied the MnCO3 as LIBs anode for the first time, which demonstrated huge potentials for Li+ ions storage [29]. After this, researches about the synthetic method, electrochemical reaction mechanism, and performance optimization of TMCs have mushroomed. The distinct advantages of TMCs as LIBs anode should be summarized as follows: (i) high theoretical capacities of more than 1000 mAh g−1 could be achieved, based on the conversion reaction along with other covert electrochemical processes; (ii) the working voltage is higher than that of the graphite anode, avoiding the generation of lithium dendrite and some unnecessary side reactions; (iii) convenient synthetic methods could cut the cost and increase the production efficiency compared with typical conversion-type anodes of TMOs, which contributes to the scaling up in practice. Despite these advantages, the lithium storage properties of TMCs are still unsatisfactory from expected anodes, because of (i) sluggish electrochemically reaction kinetics with poor electronic conductivity and (ii) structural instability due to volume variation during lithiation/delithiation processes. To overcome these drawbacks, researchers mainly focused on the structure modification and constituent optimization to improve the comprehensive electrochemical performance, in term of micro-nano structure engineering, heteroatom-doping, multifunctional compositing, and their combination. There is only one special review about TMCs anode for LIBs in 2018, which place emphasis on different metal species of TMCs [30]. However, detailed electrochemical reaction mechanism of TMCs, and intrinsic correlation between the modification strategies and electrochemical properties are not included. Moreover, to meet the rapid development of LIBs with high energy density and cyclic life, tremendous efforts regarding TMCs as well as various modification strategies, have been devoted recently, which should be summarized systematically. In this review, we emphasize the comprehensive summary about the electrochemical mechanisms, further to guide the multifarious strategies to optimize the electrochemical performance and provide distinctive views on the prospect of TMCs anodes (Fig. 1 ): (i) systematic development history of TMC anodes for LIBs has been highlighted (Fig. 2 ), and the physicochemical features of TMCs are summarized in comparison with TMOs, in view of crystal structure, electronic conductivity, and electrochemical reaction mechanism; (ii) detailed lithium storage mechanisms of TMCs anodes are across-the-board summarized, with emphases on the structure/composition characterization and electrochemical analyses; (iii) based on the understanding of electrochemical reaction mechanism as well as the intrinsic physicochemical characteristics, various strategies concerning improving the electronic/ionic conductivities, electrochemical activity, and structural integrity of TMCs are summarized; (iv) finally, the challenge for the TMCs, in terms of the electrochemical reaction mechanism and the modification of the performance, as well as the prospect for the development about the TMCs are proposed. We expect that this review could provide a systematic understanding and reference for the design and optimization of TMCs as next generation of anode active materials for rechargeable batteries. 2 Development of TMC anodes for LIBs In the early stage of LIBs field, the researches about TMCs mainly focused on the application of precursors for synthesizing TMOs anodes [40,41]. For example, to regulate the structure of Mn2O3, the fabrication of MnCO3 precursors with different sizes and morphologies was studied systematically by a pH-mediated chemical approach, which then were decomposed at high temperature to obtain the corresponding oxides counterparts [42]. Du et al. also reported that the mesoporous Co3O4 microcubes could be prepared from cantaloupe-like CoCO3 crystals by annealing in air [43]. Moreover, the TMCs could also be used to prepare the polymetallic oxides. Wang et al. [44] and Zhou et al. [45] reported the preparation of porous or hollow ZnMn2O4 spheres by calcinating the ZnMnCO3. Generally, with the release of CO2 and CO gases during the decomposition process of TMCs, the corresponding TMOs products always possess porous structure with a huge specific surface, which are beneficial for improving the electrochemical performance when used as promising anodes for LIBs. Therefore, until that moment, the TMCs are still regarded as ideal and frequently-used precursors for the fabrication of TMOs. Since 2007, Aragón et al. found that the MnCO3 prepared by the reverse-micelles method showed electrochemical energy-storage activity, which initiated the research of TMCs directly as the LIBs anode [29]. The MnCO3 with the discharging products of Li2CO3 exhibits a theoretical reversible capacity of 466 mAh g−1 (based on the reaction of MnCO3 + 2Li ↔ Li2CO3 + Mn) and superb stability, which is much better than the MnO counterparts obtained from the calcination of MnCO3 at 400 °C. Simultaneously, various researches have also certificated the superior electrochemical performance of TMCs than TMOs, in terms of excellent specific capacity and ultra-long cycling performance. For example, monodisperse CoCO3 microspindles possessed superior capacity of 1065 mAh g−1, which was 48.2% higher than that of the CoO with comparable structures (∼720 mAh g−1 after first cycles). This should be caused by their unique crystal structure, electron/ion conductivity, as well as the multistep reaction process. The crystal structure, band gaps, preparation methods, electrochemical reaction mechanisms, and electrochemical performances of TMCs are compared with those of TMOs in Table 1 . Compared with TMOs, developing TMCs directly as electrode materials has some merits in the preparation process without high-temperature calcination, such as lower production cost, increased preparation efficiency, and easy realization of straightforward scaling up. And with the complicated reaction process, the TMCs exhibited superb electrochemical performance as promising anode materials. Following, the crystal structure, electronic conductivity and reaction mechanism of TMCs are compared with those of TMOs. (i) Crystal structure TMCs, such as MnCO3, CoCO3, and FeCO3, are usually indexed as hexagonal structure. In this hexagonal structure, MO6 (M = Mn, Co, and Fe etc.) octahedra with CO3 equilateral triangles occupies the same plane, which is perpendicular to the z-axis of the hexagonal lattice [46]. Due to the large ionic radius of CO3 2− ions, TMCs tends to grow up to micro-sized particles with square or spherical morphology. Moreover, the hydroxy-carbonates, such as the Co2(OH)2CO3, generally exhibit monoclinic structure, which are inclined to grow into the lamella [47]. On the other hand, the crystal structures of TMOs are different from the TMCs. The multi-valence states TMOs (such as MnO2, Fe2O3) present various structural forms, in terms of the α-, β-, γ-, δ-, ε-, and λ-type with layer, 3D, or tunnel morphology, which are decided by the linking ways of the basic MO x unit [48–50]. It should be noted that crystal structure plays a critical role on the electrochemical performance, in view of the structural stability during charging/discharging processes and ion/electrons transfer abilities. Generally, the structures with broader channels could provide high-speed paths, thus ensuring better rate capabilities and more stable electrode structure. Therefore, regulating the architectures with micro-nano structure, expedite ion diffusion channel and electrolyte permeation route are effective strategies to enhance the electrochemical energy storage ability. (ii) Electronic conductivity The charge conductivities of the electrode, including the ionic conduction and electrical conduction, are of vital importance on the electrochemical performance. Thereinto, the electronic conductivity is key to electrochemical reaction activity as well as collecting and transport electrons to current collector [51–53]. Higher electronic conductivity could ensure faster charge transferring and better electrochemical performances. Generally, the electronic conductivity of the electrodes could be roughly evaluated by band gaps. According to the DFT calculations, TMCs exhibit band gaps fluctuate from 1.85–3.80 eV (for example, ∼3.10 eV for MnCO3, 1.85 eV for CoCO3, 3.78 eV for ZnCO3), which is similar with that for TMOs, but still insufficient for the practical application. Therefore, to improve the energy storage ability of TMCs, many researches are aimed to enhance the electron conductivity. (iii) Reaction mechanism Commonly, the electrochemical reaction mechanisms of transition metal compounds in LIBs can be divided into the intercalation–deintercalation reaction and conversion reaction. For example, the Li ions insert into the interlamination of the transition metal oxide, such as TiO2, to form Lithium-containing oxides Li n M x O y [54–56]. The intercalation-extraction reaction mechanism possesses minor volume change, but the lowest specific capacity. Most of the transition metal compounds, especially the TMOs (such as ferrous oxide, cobalt oxide, and nickel oxide etc.), store Li ions through the conversion reaction mechanism with the formation of metal elements and Li2O. During this process, a high capacity can be achieved with conversion of polyvalent metal ions, but the huge volume variation during the conversion reactions may induce poor cycling stability [57]. For TMCs, the reaction possesses are more complex and uncertain, which may involve the conversion reaction, catalytic reaction and alloying reaction. We will discuss the reaction mechanism for TMCs in details below. 3 Electrochemical reaction mechanisms of TMCs Nowadays, a lot of studies have been devoted to explore the electrochemical reaction mechanisms of TMCs anode. However, limited by technological methods and the complexity of lithiation/delithiation processes, the electrochemical reaction mechanisms of TMCs still remain ambiguous. Generally, the conversion process based on redox, as the widely accepted electrochemical reaction of transition metal compounds, is also deemed to be the principle lithiation/delithiation processes for TMCs. Subsequently, alloying/dealloying processes, multi-valence changing, pseudo-capacitance behavior, and catalytic conversion process are put forward as the potential second step for lithium storage, which can provide extra active sites for more lithium ions and thus improving the capacity [28,71]. 3.1 Conversion reaction mechanism Transition metal compounds possess high theoretical specific capacities based on the redox reaction between the transition-metal cations and Li+ along with the formation of transition metal (M) and Li n X, which is so-called conversion reaction and can be described as the formula (1): (1) M a X b +(bn)Li++(bn)e−↔aM + bLi n X According to this reaction process, the as-formed M particles are embedded in the amorphous Li n X matrix at full delithiation state, which induce the multi-electrons transferring and high specific capacities [72]. The TMCs anodes also character the conversion reaction as the dominant lithium storage process. Taking MnCO3 as an example, the conversion reaction should be described as MnCO3 + 2Li ↔ Mn + Li2CO3, in which two Li+ are involved per mole to deliver a theoretical value of 466 mAh g−1 [29]. Using the lattice-scale in-situ transmission electron microscopy (in-situ TEM), the tiny expand/shrink of MnCO3 induced by Li+ ions insertion/extraction was captured (Fig. 3 a), implying the occurrence of conversion reaction [35]. Combined electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) and magnetic measurements, Mirhashemihaghighi et al. testified the reduction of Mn2+ to Mn0 involved in the lithium storage process of Mn-based TMCs [73]. Notably, considerable amount of studies reported that TMCs presented a significantly higher capacity more than twice of the theoretical value, which is even higher than those of homologous TMOs. For example, Aragón et al. [32]. showed that the submicrometric MnCO3 particles exhibited discharge capacities of 1600 and 750 mAh g−1 at the first and second cycles, respectively. The porous MnCO3 nanospheres can maintain a high capacity of 1049 mAh g−1 with a Coulombic efficiency of ca. 99% at the current density of 1000 mA g−1 [35]. The unexpected superior electrochemical performance with excess capacity over the theoretical value implies another covered electrochemical reaction for TMCs. Here some covered in-depth mechanisms following the essential conversion reaction are summarized in Fig. 3, with particular respect to their characterization. 3.2 Pseudocapacitance-type reaction mechanism The pseudocapacitance-type electrochemical process was first put forward by Conway and Gileadi in 1962, which involves three different types: (i) adsorption pseudocapacitance (monolayer adsorption pseudocapacitance); (ii) intercalation pseudocapacitance (solid-solution electrochemical intercalation process); and (iii) redox pseudocapacitance (Faradaic reaction process) [76,77]. For the TMCs, the electrochemical behaviors are closely associated with the particle size, which mainly occurs at the electrode/electrolyte interface or near-surface to provide high power/energy density [78]. Therefore, nanostructured TMC electrode with high specific surface area and abundant pore structure can enlarge the contact area between electrode and electrolyte, reduce ions diffusion distance, and enhance the electrochemical kinetic [79,80]. For example, the galvanostatic discharge curve of the flower-like MnCO3 could be divided into three regions determined by the differential capacity (dQ/dV) curves [74]. The three processes corresponded to homogeneous Li+ insertion into the electrode, typical redox reaction, and interfacial lithium storage, respectively (Fig. 3d–f). Except the capacity from conversion reaction, the “extra” capacity could be attributed to the lithium storage at the electrode/electrolyte interface (i.e., pseudocapacitance), of which the capacity ratio reached up to ca. 30%. Due to this pseudocapacitance process, fast electrochemical reaction kinetics and capacity increasement were obtained for the MnCO3 electrode. During the charging/discharging processes of LIBs anodes, a polymeric gel-like film could be commonly observed on the surface of electrode, which is generated from the electrochemical decomposition of electrolyte and electrochemically reversible. It should be noted that the polymeric gel-like film could provide extrinsic capacity and causes the increase of the capacity with repeated cycling. In 2002, Laruelle et al. [81] confirmed that the polymeric gel-like films on the surface of CoO electrode was dynamic, which grew at low potential of ca. 0.2 V and disappeared at 2.0 V by the detailed analyses of cyclic voltammogram. While for the TMCs, Zhou et al. [82] reported a rambutan-like FeCO3 hollow microspheres, delivering a high initial charge/discharge capacity of 925/1730 mAh g−1 and a gradually ascending capacity of 800 mAh g−1 at the 20th cycle. Note that the theoretical specific capacity of FeCO3 based on the conversion reaction (FeCO3 + 2Li+ + 2e− ↔ Fe + Li2CO3) is calculated to be only 462 mAh g−1. The extra lithium storage capacity for the FeCO3 hollow microspheres was attributed to two parts: (i) the pseudocapacitance contribution from the reversible generation/decomposition of the polymer/gel-like film; (ii) the pseudocapacitance capacity from the interfacial reaction induced by the highly porous structure with large surface area. Besides the FeCO3, the CoCO3 anode also demonstrated much higher specific capacities than theoretical value. For example, the dumbbells-like CoCO3 and rhombohedra CoCO3 delivered high specific capacities of 1175 and 973 mAh g−1, respectively. Due to the high specific surface area and pore architecture of these two kinds of CoCO3, the high capacities were partly ascribed to the polymer/gel-like film on the electrode surface. Rezvani et al. [83] detailedly analyzed the composition change of the electrolyte interphase using high resolution soft X-ray absorption (XAS) combined with X-ray photoemission spectroscopy (XPS) to explain the evolution of this polymeric gel-like film. The XAS spectra of C and Li K-edge TEY (Fig. 4 ) as well as the O K-edge TEY and TFY spectra indicated that the Li2CO3 and LiF are formed at the initial cycles on the surface of the electrode. And then the peak assigned to ROCO2Li abruptly increased below 0.7 V and gradually reduced during the delithiation process. This dynamic and reversible variation process of ROCO2Li in the surface polymer/gel-like film additionally contributed to the capacity with experimentally evaluated to be ca. 265 mAh g−1, which is about up to 40% of the extra-capacity. It is worth noting that the pseudocapacitance-type charge storage heavily relies on the nanostructure of active material as well as the components of the electrolyte. Therefore, constructing micro-nano structure with abundant electrode/electrolyte interface is deemed to be as an effective strategy to improve the lithium storage capacity of TMC anodes. 3.3 Valence variation for charge storage In some cases, the ever-rising capacity for TMCs upon cycling could be detected, especially for the Mn-based TMCs. To explore the inner reaction mechanism, Li et al. [36] carefully studied the CV curves of Ni/Zn co-doped MnCO3 (Mn content: 80%, Ni content: 12%, and Zn content: 8%). It was found that in the initial CV process, the main anodic peak at 1.22 V represented the oxidation of Mn0 to MnⅡ. During the subsequent cycles, new peaks emerged at 1.82 and 2.22 V, which got more and more stronger with the cycles going on, indicating the gradually intensified oxidation of MnⅡ to higher valence Mn ions. As a result of the multiple-stage redox reaction of Mn species, a superior reversible capacity of 1066 mAh g−1 was achieved after 500 cycles, higher than the capacity of 819 mAh g−1 at 43th cycle. Similarly, the MnCO3/reduced graphene oxide (MnCO3/RGO) composite with a steadily ascending capacities from 880 to 1450 mAh g−1 after 200 cycles was also reported at the current density of 200 mA g−1 [84]. Combining the gradually emerged and rising peak pairs in CV curves and corresponding reaction platforms in discharge–charge plots after 50 cycles, with the enhanced peaks assigned to MnIV by the XPS measurement, the researchers confirmed that the re-oxidation of MnⅡ to higher valences, such as MnIII or MnIV, accounted for the enhancement of specific capacity. Moreover, the graphene-wrapped mesoporous MnCO3 composites also demonstrated a slowly increased capacity upon 1000 mAh g−1, which is twice of the theoretical capacity based on conversion reaction [85]. Combined the CV curves and discharge–charge plots, the further oxidation of MnⅡ to MnIV was also certified and the phenomenon of capacity increasement was clarified. In fact, the valence change of metal cations was also observed in other transition metal compounds, especially the Mn-based TMOs [86–88], such as MnO/graphene hybrid [89], bimetallic oxide ZnMn2O4 [90], in which the re-oxidation of MnⅡ to higher state (III and/orIV) contributed to the increased capacity. It is worthy to be mentioned that in the reported Mn-based compounds, valence variation and gradually ascending capacity mostly occurred in the composites with carbon components or multiple transition metal compounds [91–94]. While for the pure MnCO3 or Mn x O y , the valence variation was suppressed. For example, only one pair of redox peaks at ca. 0.3/1.1 V were observed for the CV curves of pure MnO x , corresponding to the redox reaction of MnⅡ/Mn0. But a new pair of peaks at ca. 1.1/1.8 V gradually emerged with enhanced intensity upon cycling for the MnO/carbon composites, indicating the further reaction between MnⅡ and higher oxidation state Mn [50,95–97]. For TMCs, the MnCO3/graphene composites also demonstrated two gradually emerged plateaus in the galvanostatic discharge/charge profiles after 50 cycles, implying the further oxidation of MnⅡ. However, no similar plateaus were observed for pure MnCO3 particles [59,98]. Therefore, some synergistic effects were generated with the carbon materials or heterogeneous transition metals during the electrochemical reaction, which could promote more electrons participating the lithiation/delithation processes. However, rare reports have covered this point with detailed analysis, which is highly desired to understand the electrochemical mechanism of transition metal compounds. 3.4 Catalytic conversion mechanism Generally, after the first-step conversion reaction, the Li2CO3 matrix can be further electrochemically decomposed with the help of nano-sized metal particles (M) to realize the reversible reaction, which involves more electron transfer and enhances the electrochemical performance [99]. This process is the catalytic conversion process, which initially originated from the mechanism study for the electrochemical reduction of carbon dioxide. In 1990, Masashi et al. investigated the electrochemical reduction of carbon dioxide on 32 kinds of metal electrodes in aqueous KHCO3 solution, in which the non-noble metal including Mn and Co was found to exhibit catalytic activity for converting C4+ to low valence C species [100]. Then, researches about nanostructured non-noble metal catalysts for electrochemical CO2 reduction sprung up, while the electrocatalytic capabilities were vastly improved [101,102]. In 2013, Su et al. reported the CoCO3/graphene composite with ultrahigh initial discharge capacity of 1980 mAh g−1, as well as 930 mAh g−1 after 40 cycles, much higher than the theoretical value of CoCO3 (450 mAh g−1 based on the conversion reaction) [33]. A new electrochemical lithiation/delithiation behavior for TMCs was proposed by unveiling the fact that the Li2CO3 generated from the initial conversion process, could be reversibly decomposed and formed under the catalysis of nano-sized transition metal particles. To clarify this new paradigm, SAED, HRTEM and XPS measurements were used to detect the component change of lithiated CoCO3/PTFE electrode without extra carbon. Firstly, the SAED pattern reflected the diffraction rings of Li2O (1 0 0), (1 1 - 1), Co (0 0 1) and Li2CO3 (1 3 0), (2 2 3 - ), which were coincided to the HRTEM results. Moreover, high-resolution XPS spectrum of C element was divided to C–C (284.5 eV) and C–F/C=O (286.6 eV) from PTFE, C–OR (285.3 eV) from the SEI layer, and C=C (292.0 eV) indicating the C or low-valence C species from the decomposition of Li2CO3 and residual Li2CO3 (289.7 eV). The Li 1s and O 1s spectra were also fitted with Li2O and Li2CO3. Following this concept, Ding et al. [103] speculated this reaction mechanism for CoCO3 as the formulas below: (2) CoCO3 + 2Li+ + 2e−↔Co + Li2CO3 (3) Li 2 CO 3 + ( 4 + 0.5 x ) Li + + ( 4 + 0.5 x ) e - ↔ Co 3 Li 2 O + 0.5 Li x C 2 ( x = 0 , 1 , 2 ) The second reaction process was triggered under the catalysis of metallic Co nanoparticles, which manifested high electrocatalytic activity to reduction activation energy and chemically combined with C=O bonds to facilitate the decomposition of Li2CO3.With the two-steps reaction, up to 7Li+ could be stored for each CoCO3 (x = 2 in Equation (3)), resulting in an ultrahigh theoretical capacity of 1610 mAh g−1, coincident well with the experimental results. Combining ex-situ Raman, FTIR, and HRTEM measurements, Chen et al. verified the reversible reduction/formation of Li2CO3 (Fig. 3i and j) [75]. When discharged to 0.7 V, two new Raman spectra emerged at 1940 and 2060 cm−1, corresponding to the Li2C2 and acetylene by-products, respectively, while the initial peak for Li2CO3 disappeared. When the cell was charged to 2 V back, the Raman peaks for Li2CO3 re-appeared along with the decreased intensity of Li2C2. Ex-situ FTIR and HRTEM tests further indicated the decomposition of Li2CO3 to Li2C2 and Li2O below 0.7 V and the re-formation of Li2CO3 and CoCO3 above charged potential of 2.0 V. This catalytic reaction was also observed in Co2(OH)2CO3/rGO composites in which the Li2CO3, Li x C2, LiOH, LiH, and Li2O were detected by ex-situ XPS spectra, clearly. TEM images of the electrode after fully discharging also showed the lattice distances with 2.11 Å for Co (100), 2.81 Å for Li2CO3 (002), 2.68 Å for Li2O (111), 2.57 Å for LiC (032), and 3.60 Å for Li2C2 (011), indicating the further decomposition of the conversion reaction products (Li2CO3), as shown in Fig. 5 (a–e) [38]. Moreover, in-situ XRD measurement detected the conversion process from Co2(OH)2CO3/rGO to Co (111) and deeply reduction to LiF (111), LiOH and Li x C2 (002), further demonstrating the catalytic reaction process in TMCs (Fig. 5f) [104]. Except the Co-based carbonates, the extra capacities for other TMCs, such as FeCO3 and MnCO3, also can be ascribed to the catalysis mechanism [28,62,105,106]. Notably, the Li2CO3 plays multiple roles during the electrochemical process. As summarized above, Li2CO3 is the main discharge product of the TMC during lithiation process, and could further react with Li+ to provide extra capacity. Moreover, Li2CO3 is also a major component in the SEI film for most electrodes, which greatly impacts on the compaction, thickness as well as stability of SEI film [108,109]. In this regard, how to utilize the Li2CO3 effectively is critical to improve the electrochemical stability and specific capacity of the anode. Recently, researchers found that Li2CO3 could be utilized as the additive to optimize the electrochemical performance. In 2004, Mukai et al. found that when the micropores of amorphous carbon were plugged or partially filled by the Li2CO3 additive, the reversible capacity of amorphous carbon increased accompanied with decreased irreversible capacity [110]. This should be due to that the plugged pores by Li2CO3 could prevent large volume change of carbon during charge/discharge processes, leading to better Coulombic efficiency and reversibility. Moreover, Komaba et al. proved that multiple alkali carbonates, such as 1 wt.% Li2CO3, 5 wt.% Na2CO3, 1 wt.% K2CO3, could also suppress the irreversible reaction on the surface of graphite by modifying the SEI layer [111]. More recently, Yang et al. reported a hierarchical structure with amorphous Li2CO3 coated on α-Fe2O3 [107]. As shown in Fig. 5(g), by ball milling the mixture of Fe2O3 and LiH under CO2 atmosphere, the reaction as Equation (4) shown could be triggered: (4) 3Fe2O3 + 6LiH + CO2 → Li2CO3 + 2Li2Fe3O4 + 3H2 (ball milling) by which the inert Li2CO3 was formed and then conformally coated on the surface of Fe2O3. With the compact attached Li2CO3 as a component to the stable the SEI layer, as well as the hierarchical structure with sub-micrometer (400–800 nm) of active α-Fe2O3 as core and amorphous Li2CO3 as shell, the amorphous Li2CO3-coated Fe2O3 hierarchical nanostructure demonstrated super electrochemical stability compared with the pristine Fe2O3 and the simple mixture of Fe2O3/Li2CO3. Moreover, the general applicability of this coating technique was developed to the NiO, which further confirmed that the thin amorphous Li2CO3 and Li2O layers can efficiently promote the long-term cycling performance. In fact, except in the TMCs, the decomposition of Li-contained salts, such as Li2SO4 and Li2C8H4O4, under the catalytic effect of metal nanoparticles during electrochemical process have been reported in other transition metal compounds [100]. For instance, triggered by the fresh metallic Fe0 nanocrystals formed by the conversion reaction of Fe3O4, the electrocatalytic reduction of C4+ in carbonate salts to lower valence C species provided extra capacity, much higher than the value based on the conversion mechanism [112]. Similarly, for the CoSO4 encapsulated by carbon and graphene, the multi-step reactions contributed the outstanding electrochemical capacity, which involved the committed step of the catalyzation of Co on SO4 2− as Equations (5) and (6) [113]. (5) CoSO4 + 2Li++2e−↔Co + Li2SO4 (6) SO 4 2 - + 8 Li + + 8 e - ↔ Co S + 4 Li 2 O Moreover, Hong et al. clearly demonstrated the reversible reaction of organic terephthalate ligands in the transition metal (Ni or Fe) terephthalate anode by X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) and nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) measurements [114]. These results indicated a two-step electrochemical reaction mechanism for the excessive capacity, as described in Equations. (7) and (8): (7) Ni(II)C8H4O4 + 2(Li++e−) ↔ Ni(0) + Li2C8H4O4, (8) Ni(0) + Li2C8H4O4+(x − 2)Li++(x − 2)e−↔Ni(0) + Li x C8H4O4 which accounts for (i) the reduction of divalent Ni2+ ions to fresh metal nanoparticles with average sizes less than 5 nm; (ii) the successive lithiation of the as-formed Li2C8H4O4 to generate more saturated organic scaffolds Li x C8H4O4 (x > 2) under the catalysis of Ni nanoparticles. Although the further reduction of the Li-contained salts can provide extra capacity, it also may hamper the electrochemical performance of the LIBs. Taken the TMCs as an example, the decomposition of Li2CO3 product can trigger some serious problems. (i) The decomposition of Li2CO3 may generate gas, and is unsafe in practical LIBs. For example, the Ni-rich cathode contains Li2CO3 on the order of 0.3–0.6 wt%, of which the decomposition to form CO2 could cause a substantial bulging of the cell, leading to the potential safety hazard [115]. (ii) The decomposition of Li2CO3 causes the structure change of SEI layer. As an important component of the SEI layer, the decomposition of Li2CO3 would certainly induce the structural destruction and the rebuilding of SEI layer, leading to the continuous consumption of electrolyte and capacity decaying. How to balance this process is important to obtain the high specific capacity and long cycling stability. Briefly, the catalysis reaction mechanism for TMCs is a complicated process involving the nanometer effect of metal particles and the decomposition of Li2CO3, in which the specific influence factor and detailed reaction process are still ambiguity and in dispute until now. 3.5 Other reaction mechanism Except the pseudocapacitance-type charge storage including the reversible decomposition/formation of SEI layer and the polymeric/gel-like film, the multi-valence change process involved in Mn-based and Co-based TMCs, as well as the catalysis conversion mechanism proposing the further decomposition of the discharge product Li2CO3 under the catalytic effect of metal nanoparticles, some other mechanisms are also suggested for the TMCs. Cao et al. proposed the alloying reaction mechanism for MnCO3 following Equations (9) and (10): (9) MnCO3 + 2Li ↔ Mn0 + Li2CO3 (10) Mn + xLi+↔MnLi x by which a high specific capacity up to 857 mAh g−1 was maintained after 100 cycles [116]. Moreover, the lithium storage mechanisms of TMCs analogues were also investigated, such as Ni(HCO3)2 [37], Co2(OH)2CO3 [117] and Co(Ac)2− x (OH) x [118]. Dong et al. reported a 3D layered Ni(HCO3)2/rGO nanoarchitecture as LIBs anodes and studied the detailed electrochemical reaction mechanism with in-situ XRD and CV curves [37]. The lithiation behaviors were very complex, involving the conversion reaction as the first lithiation step based on Equation (11) and further lithiation/delithiation based on Equations (12)–(14): (11) Ni(HCO3)2 + 2Li++2e−→2LiHCO3 + Ni (12) 2 LiHCO 3 + ( 8 + x ) Li + + ( 8 + x ) e - ↔ Ni 4 Li 2 O + 2 LiOH + Li x C 2 ( x = 0 - - 2 ) (13) Ni + Li2O ↔ NiO + 2Li++2e− (14) NiO + 0.5Li2O ↔ 0.5Ni2O3 + Li++e− Due to the multielectron-involved conversion reaction of Ni(HCO3)2 and further reaction of the Ni and NiO, as well as the catalytic reaction under Ni nanoparticles during the charge/discharge process, the Ni(HCO3)2/rGO composite exhibited ultrahigh reversible capacity of 1535 mAh g−1 at a current density of 5 A g−1 after 1000 cycles. The above reaction mechanisms were also certified by the hierarchal Ni(HCO3)2/carbon nanofibers composites, for which a high initial discharge/charge capacity of 3807/1261 mAh g−1 was achieved [119]. The metal carbonate hydroxide is another kind of TMCs analogues. Liu’s group [117] and Shen’s group [47] reported the fabrication of cobalt carbonate hydroxide (Co2(OH)2CO3) nanosheets on the GO template. Combined with Raman, XRD, and HRTEM, two kinds of crystallo-graphically different Co2+ were found in the Co2(OH)2CO3, which induced the in-situ phase separation into CoCO3 and Co(OH)2 during the initial lithiation/delithiation processes (Fig. 6 ). Then the Li+ ions were stored through two separated electrochemical reaction of CoCO3 and Co(OH)2 as shown in Equations (15)–(17) [104]: (15) Step Ⅰ: Co2(OH)2CO3 + 4Li++4e−↔2Co + Li2CO3 + 2LiOH (16) Step II : Li 2 CO 3 + ( 4 + 0.5 x ) Li + + ( 4 + 0.5 x ) e - ↔ Co 3 Li 2 O + 0.5 ( Li x C 2 ) ( x = 0 , 1 2 ) , (17) LiOH + 2Li++2e−↔Li2O + LiH The different lithiation/delithiation potentials of the Co(OH)2 and CoCO3 could hinder the coarsening of same crystal zones and enhance the structural stability. Due to these multi-step reactions and the synergistic effect, the Co2(OH)2CO3 demonstrated a high theoretical capacity up to 1644 mAh g−1, and superior cycling stability with reversible capacity of 550 mAh g−1 at 10 A g−1 after 5000 cycles [104,120]. It should be noted that except the TMCs, the other oxysalt, such as the metal acetates and sulphates, also exhibits similar electrocatalytic reaction mechanism [121]. In 2017, Zhou et al. reported the superior lithium storage performance of layered hydroxide cobalt acetates (Co(Ac)2− x (OH) x ) anchored on graphene nanosheets [118]. The authors proposed a novel model of electrocatalytic conversion mechanism, in which the Co(Ac)2− x (OH) x was decomposed into LiOH and LiAc after the first cycle. Then, the LiOH and LiAc acted as the new-generated active materials, further storing Li+ ions under the catalysis of fresh Co nanoparticles following Equations. (18)–(20): (18) Step Ⅰ: Co(Ac)2− x (OH) x + 2Li ↔ Co + xLiOH+(2 − x)LiAc (19) Step II:LiOH + 2 Li ↔ Co Li 2 O + LiH (20) LiAc + Li ↔ Co CH 3 CHO + Li 2 O Owing to the continuous electrochemical process and the novel architecture of the Co(Ac)2− x (OH) x nanoplates face-to-face anchored on the graphene, this composite exhibited superior long-term stability and high-rate capabilities. 4 Synthesis methods Due to the thermal instability, the synthetic process of TMCs generally excludes high-temperature annealing process, which is almost essential for the fabrication and structural design of most transition metal compounds. In this regard, the TMCs are obtained through simply one-step liquid-phase process. Particularly, the common liquid-phase synthetic methods mainly include the solvothermal process and the precipitation process. (1) Precipitation process Precipitation approach is an easy and fast method to fabricate the micro-nano particles. In this method, the precipitator is indispensable for preparing TMCs. The common precipitators include Na2CO3, NaHCO3, (NH4)2CO3, NH4HCO3 [122]. Deng et al. reported the fabrication of Ni0.13Mn0.54(CO3)0.8 with the metallic sulfate and Na2CO3 precipitator in the de-ionized water under vigorous stirring [123]. Under the alkalescent atmosphere, the precipitation process occurred between metal cations and CO3 2−, and the final carbonates particles with quasi-spherical shape and a diameter of 8–12 μm were obtained. Moreover, the CoCO3/RGO composites were also prepared by the precipitation between CoCl2 .6H2O and Na2CO3, followed by further assembly with RGO nanosheets [124]. Moreover, the dropping speed of precipitator and the types of the solution have great influence on the microstructure of TMCs. By gradually decreasing the titrate speed of NH4HCO3 solution into the aqueous MnSO3 solution, various MnCO3 particles with controlled diameters of 6.9, 4.0, and 2.6 μm were prepared [125]. The MnCO3 with shape of nanospheres and nanocubes was obtained by adjusting the volume ratios of deionized water to ethylene glycol (EG) to 30% and 50%, respectively [126]. Moreover, the refluxing process can also be used to fabricate MnCO3 with different morphology [60]. After refluxing at 150 °C for 2 h, the white precipitate and dark brown solution were got. Thereinto, the hierarchical architecture MnCO3 microdumbbells were obtained from the white precipitate, and the lamellar structured MnCO3 nanosheets could be collected from the dark-brown solution. Due to the unique micro-nano structure, the microdumbbells exhibited better electrochemical performance. (2) Solvothermal process Solvothermal process demonstrates great effectiveness on regulating the particle size, morphology, and uniformity of the micro-nano architecture. For the synthesis of TMCs with solvothermal process, except the traditional precipitator such as Na2CO3 and NaHCO3, urea also can produce CO3 2− under high temperature and high pressure. This kind of reaction is progressive and occurs in the whole system, so that the obtained TMCs products is highly uniform in size and microstructure [120,127]. During the solvothermal process, the type of solvent, reaction temperature and time, chelating agents play vital roles on regulating the size and microstructure of TMCs. In our recent work, the CoCO3 with different morphology and pore structure was prepared by adjusting the solvents from deionized water, ethylene glycol to diethylene glycol [128]. Due to the difference of polarity and viscosity for these solvents, the ions diffusion rate and nucleating kinetics of nanocrystals are different, which induce the distinction of the final particle and pore sizes, and further influence the electrochemical performance. Moreover, during the solvothermal process, the chelating agents can provide abundant functional groups to adjust the morphology of the products. Generally, the cetyl-trimethyl ammonium bromide, ascorbic acid, sodium dodecyl sulfate (SDS) and so on are deemed as the active additive, which will be discussed in the micro-nano engineering section. Here, the graphite oxide (GO) could be regarded as an effective chelating agent. When dispersed in the deionized water, GO suspension is formed. In this colloid-like suspension, the abundant oxygen-containing functional groups on the GO sheets can adsorb metal ions, and the enhanced viscosity of the solution can limit the growth kinetic [129,130]. Finally, uniformly distributed and size-limited carbonates particles are adhered or wrapped by the graphene sheets, which can promote the electron conductivity and structural integrate of TMCs [47,131]. 5 Strategies to improve electrochemical performance Based on the reaction mechanisms and intrinsic characteristic, the development bottlenecks of TMCs mainly involves the following. (i) The insulator/semiconductor nature of TMCs. The band gaps for TMCs fluctuate from 1.85 to 3.8 eV, indicating a deficient electronic conductivity, which severely restricts the rate performance especially under large current density. (ii) The volume expansion due to the conversion reaction process. With conversion reaction of TMCs (MCO3 + 2Li++2e−↔M + Li2CO3), 2 mol of Li ion would be in 1 mol of TMCs. And during this process, the phase and structure changed in the active materials, leading to the relatively large volume change about 200%, which further decrease the cycling stability of TMCs. Therefore, aiming to settle the intrinsic deficiencies, including low electronic conductivity, sluggish electrochemical reaction kinetics, and volume expansion, various strategies are proposed based on the electrochemical reaction mechanisms of TMCs. Firstly, constructing TMCs with hierarchical micro-/nano structure could shorten ion diffusion path and accommodate the volume change during Li+ insert/extract processes. Secondly, the doping strategy, especially the mixed TMCs with two or more metal species in one crystal cell, could effectively improve the electrochemical activity. Thirdly, hybridizing TMC with conductive carbon materials or/and electrochemically active transition metal compounds could achieve a comprehensive performance, in view of stable cyclic performance, enhanced specific capacity, and excellent rate capabilities. 5.1 Robust TMC architectures: micro-nano engineering Generally, the Li+ ions diffusion time (τ) in the transition metal compounds mainly depends on the diffusion length (λ) and diffusivity (D i) according to the relationship τ = λ2/D i, in which λ is determined by the size or dimension of electrode materials, while D i represents the Li+ diffusion capability or the ease of Li+ movement in the electrode [132,133]. For a given material, the diffusion diffusivity is a constant, so that the τ quadratically relies on the λ. Hence, decreasing the λ by reducing the particle size of active material can vastly shorten the Li+ ions diffusion time [134–137]. In addition, nanosized active materials could provide abundant Li + storage sites for high capacity. However, TMCs nanoparticles tended to agglomerate together during the electrode preparation and charging/discharging processes, resulting in rapid capacity fading. On the other hand, hierarchical micro-structures consisting of nanoscale building blocks are compatible to achieve high electrochemical capacity and stable cycling performance. Firstly, micron-sized structures with relatively low specific surface area could inhibit the particle aggregation, thus maintaining stable electrode architecture and active sites. Secondly, the nanoscale building blocks could retain the excellent structural features of nanomaterials, including abundant electrochemically active sites, shortened Li+ diffusion path, and fast reaction kinetics. Thirdly, the micro-nano structured materials are always porous with hierarchical architecture, which is very favorable for electrolyte infiltration and rapid mass/ions transportation [138,139]. Thus, micro-nano structured TMCs, including square [32,140], ellipsoidal [34,141], hollow microspheres [82,142], microdumbbells and nanosheets [60], have been designed and prepared to improve the ion transfer kinetics and achieve high electrochemical performances. To enhance the electrochemical kinetics and short the ion diffusion path, the porous structure of TMCs have been designed. Kang et al. synthesized porous MnCO3 spheres with the surface area of 25.4 m2 g−1, a pore volume of 0.188 cm3 g−1, and an average pore diameter of 3.2 nm [35]. With these structural advantages, the porous MnCO3 spheres exhibited superior rate in view of high discharge capacities of 1284, 1200, 1138, 1038, 700 and 252 mAh g−1, at the current densities of 100, 500, 1000, 2000, 5000 and 10000 mA g−1, respectively, and excellent cyclic performance (a high specific capacity of ca. 1049 mAh g−1 with a Coulombic efficiency about 99% at 1000 mA g−1). Moreover, with the effect of AA during the hydrothermal process, peanut-like hierarchical MnCO3 microcrystals assembled with floss-like nanowires were obtained [143]. Compared with the MnCO3 nanoparticles with high contact resistance, the peanut-like MnCO3 electrodes provided more active sites and continuous paths for electrons/ions transfer, which were more favorable for improved electrochemical capacity. Elaborate design of hierarchical micro-nano architecture is essential to reduce the electron/ion transfer length, increase electrolyte/electrode contract area, thus enhancing the electrochemical performance [57,144–148]. Due to the limited heat resistance, solvothermal process is the main method to fabricate TMCs with hierarchical micro-nano architecture. Generally, chelating agent, such as the organic acids with low-molecular-weight and surfactant, is essential in the solvothermal process, which can not only positively affect the nucleation and growth of nanocrystals by forming a protective layer on the surfaces, but also enhance the electrostatic stabilization [123,150,151]. Cao et al. explored the influence of CTAB on the morphology of MnCO3 (Fig. 7 a–c) [71]. The submicron peanut-like MnCO3 with irregular nanoparticles (SPs) was obtained during the solvothermal process, contrasted with the square MnCO3 (SQs) under the addition of CTAB. Due to the high specific surface area (110.27 vs. 0.467 m2 g−1 for SPs vs. SQs) and the abundant pore structure (0.144 vs. 0.002 cm3 g−1 for SPs vs. SQs), the SPs demonstrated a stable capacity of 700 mAh g−1 after 140 cycles at the current density of 233 mA g−1. While the SQs delivered a higher capacity of 1532 mAh g−1 at the initial cycle, which decayed rapidly to 500 mAh g−1. AA has also been adopted as another chelating to adjust the microstructure of TMCs. CoCO3 nanoparticles with dumbbell-shape or rhombohedra-shape were prepared via hydrothermal method in the presence and absence of AA, respectively, as shown in Fig. 7(d–f) [63]. Time-dependent experiments show that in the absence of AA, the amorphous nanoparticles from the precipitation reaction evolved from sheet-like Co2CO3(OH)2 to ultrathin sheets with oriented attachment, and finally to rhombohedral architectures through a series of dehydration, nucleation and growth. In the presence of chelating agent, AA provided active sites for the nucleation of CoCO3, which made the nanocrystals rapidly aggregated to form dumbbell-shaped particles. The effect of AA on morphology regulation was also confirmed for the fabrication of acanthosphere-shaped FeCO3 [152]. During the hydrothermal process, the Fe3+ from the FeCl3 was reduced to Fe2+ by AA, and the hydrated hydraferroes were formed at the same time. Due to the abundant hydroxyl groups on AA, the hydrated hydraferroes with high surface energy were strongly linked with AA to self-assemble into acanthosphere-shaped with low surface energy. Moreover, SDS [140], and citrate dihydrate (Na3Cit·2H2O) [98] could also be introduced as chelating agents to adjust the microstructure of TMCs. Via controlling the amount of Na2Cit and reaction time, hierarchical MnCO3 microcrystals with 3D flower-like nano-bundles and spherical MnCO3 were successfully obtained. Compared with the spherical MnCO3, the 3D flower-like MnCO3 exhibited higher specific capacity, better rate performance, and more stable electrode structure. Jana et al. systematically studied the effect of chelating agents on the morphology of MnCO3, that is, citric acid, oxalic acid, and tartaric acid [149]. With the abundant COOH groups in these acids, the Mn2+ could effectively be trapped in their cavities, and then react with the released CO3 2− in the solution to form MnCO3 with different morphology (Fig. 7g). Apart from the chelating agent, other synthesis conditions, such as solvent and reaction time, also have significant influence on adjusting the morphology and microstructure of TMCs [153,154]. By regulating the volume proportion of EG and H2O during the solvothermal process, a series of CoCO3 structures from cantaloupe-shape to microcubes were obtained, and correspondingly different physicochemical properties were achieved for these CoCO3 (Fig. 7h) [43]. Similarly, the MnCO3 nanospheres and nanocubes were also obtained by adjusting the reaction solvent matching to control the pressure and the viscosity during the hydrothermal process [126]. Therefore, regulating the proportion and variety of raw materials as well as the reaction condition (time, temperature) are vital for hierarchical micro-nano architecture engineering. Moreover, to enhance the ability for releasing the strain/stress and accommodate the volume expansion, hollow structure has demonstrated great promise for LIB anodes. Their merits, such as high surface area, low density, and short charge transport channel from the well-defined boundaries and interior cavities, endow them superior electrochemical performance [156–158]. Limited by the synthetic method, the preparation of hollow TMCs remains great challenges and difficulties [159]. Cai et al. developed a novel approach to fabricate the hollow MnCO3 [155]. Firstly, the solid MnCO3 cubes were synthesized and then buried into the trioctylphosphine oxide (TOPO) at high temperature. During this process, the TOPO molecules firstly absorbed on the surface of solid MnCO3 to form a protected layer, and then the weak acids (alkylphosphonic/alkylphosphinic acids) from the TOPO impurity etched inner carbonate to generate vacancies and CO2. Along with the continuously outward diffusion of the inner metal carbonate and the escape of CO2, pores in the voids and on the wall for the cubes were gradually formed. Finally, after refluxed and washed in hot methanol to remove the surface ligands, the hollow porous MnCO3 was synthesized. The synthetic process was schematically shown in Fig. 8 (a), and could also be extended to fabricate hollow CoCO3 rhombuses and hollow CaCO3 capsules. Moreover, under the chelating effect of AA and the symmetric inside-out Ostwald ripening, the rambutan-like FeCO3 hollow microspheres composing of one-dimension (1D) nanofiber were synthesized [82]. As shown in Fig. 8(b–d), the rambutan-like structure with nanofiber shell can accelerate the adequate permeation of electrolyte, improve the active specific area, and shorten the charge/ions transfer length. More importantly, the hollow structure with sufficient void space could effectively accommodate the large volume variation of FeCO3 to maintain electrochemically cyclic stability. Benefiting from the abundant porosity and hollow interiors, as well as the nanofibers building blocks, the hierarchical hollow FeCO3 was endowed with superior electrochemical performance. Moreover, template-engaged strategy is also effective to synthesize hollow structured TMCs. As shown in Fig. 8(e), Keasvan et al. reported the hollow MnCO3 spheres fabricated with SiO2 as the template, which demonstrated superior lithium storage properties [142]. It has been demonstrated that superior electrochemical performance can be achieved with unique micro-nano architecture and ingenious morphology [160–162]. Therefore, the merits of micro-nano structure engineering of TMCs for improved lithium storage properties should be summarized as below: (i) the micro-nano architecture characterizes large electrode/electrolyte interface area, leading to more abundant electrochemically active sites [71]; (ii) with the micro-sized particles composed with nano-sized building blocks, the micro-nano architectures possess more space to enhance the volume accommodation ability and achieve superior cycling performance; (iii) the porous structure can effectively accelerate ion diffusion, resulting in fast electrochemical reaction kinetics. Admittedly, TMCs with micro-nano structures can effectively increase the electrochemical active sites and enhance the reaction kinetics to improve the capacity to a certain extent. However, the limited synthetic methods and the thermal instability restrict the delicate structure design of TMCs, which usually requires annealing process at high temperature. In addition, the micro-nano structured TMCs still suffer from poor electronic conductivity, leading to capacity attenuation. 5.2 Heteroatom-doping strategy Heteroatom-doping strategy has demonstrated high effectivity in increasing the electronic conductivity of transition metal compounds. Generally, the doping elements could be divided into nonmetal and metal elements. For the transition metal compounds, metal cations are easier to be substituted and the influence is more conspicuous [163,164]. Specifically, the main influences of the doped heteroatom on the physic-chemistry properties are reflected on the aspects as follows. Firstly, when the dopants with larger ionic radius are doped into the crystal structure, the pristine cell would expand, leading to enlarged interplanar spacing and broadened ions transmission path. Secondly, the dopants partly substitute the host elements or enter the intervals, which could improve the conductivity with the overlapped electronic orbit and the charge distortion between the adjacent atoms. Hereon, the metal element doping strategy to improve the intrinsic is summarized, and the nonmetal dopants will be briefly introduced. (1) Metal elemental-doping Due to the sluggish electrochemical reaction kinetics and large volume expansion, the cyclic stability and rate capabilities of simple TMCs are unsatisfactory for LIBs anode. To address these defects of TMCs, a powerful strategy is to synthesize mixed TMCs with two kinds of metal elements, which demonstrated superior electrochemical performance to simple TMCs. Various metal elements including: Ni [165,166], Mn [167,168], Co [169], Cd [170], Zn [58], Sb [171] and Ca [172], have been utilized to prepare binary TMCs with enhanced ions/electrons diffusion kinetics. Generally, the TMCs with multi-type metal elements possess better electronic conductivities, which can enhance the electrochemical kinetics and rate performance. For example, Li et al. reported the partially substitution of Ni into MnCO3 to form Ni x Mn1− x CO3 (x = 0, 0.2, 0.25, 0.33) sub-micro spheres (Fig. 9 a) [166]. XRD pattern of these Ni x Mn1− x CO3 demonstrated identical crystal structures to hexagonal MnCO3, indicating no impurity in the products. Notably, the peak location of representative (104) plane of the Ni x Mn1− x CO3 regularly shifted following the increase of x without splitting, confirming the integrated lattice structure with atomic-scale distribution of Ni and Mn in the TMCs crystals. Due to the enhanced electronic conductivity induced by Ni doping, the Ni0.25Mn0.75CO3 delivered superior electrochemical performance. Similarly, Alagar et al. also proposed the doping of MnCO3 with Ni to construct single-phase Mn1− x Ni x CO3 microspheres (x = 0, 0.2, 0.25, 0.33) [173]. When evaluated as the electrode for the solid-state asymmetric supercapacitors, the appropriate Ni dopant concentration could improve the conductivity and electrochemical activity, thus leading to excellent cyclic stability. Furthermore, the Fe, Co, Ni, and Cu -doped MnCO3 were also synthesized, and these substitution atoms induced structural defects in the MnCO3 and therefore enhanced the electron conductivity, which improved the electrochemical activities [174]. The solid-state hybrid supercapacitors assembled with Fe-MnCO3//Activated carbon in PVA/KOH polymer gel electrolytes exhibited high energy density of 19.74 Wh kg−1 at power densities of 380 W kg−1 with a high capacitance retention of 82.63% after 1000 cycles. In addition, the doping strategy can further enhance the electrochemical activity of the TMCs and further promote the rate performance. Considering the larger ionic radius of Cd2+ (95 pm) than that of Fe2+ (78 pm), Kong et al. designed the Fe1− x Cd x CO3 to investigate the synergistic effect of mixed TMCs on the electrochemical performance [170]. As shown in Fig. 9(b), the crystal cell became larger (represented by a, c, and V) with the increased contents of Cd. The mixed binary Fe0.8Cd0.2CO3 maintained good conductivity similar to FeCO3 and high lithium-ion diffusion coefficient analogous to CdCO3. Taken the advantages of both FeCO3 and CdCO3, the Fe0.8Cd0.2CO3 exhibited high lithium storage capacity of 706.4 mAh g−1 after 100 cycles, much higher than that of 0.8 FeCO3 + 0.2 CdCO3 mixtures (164.5 mAh g−1). To achieve high dopant content without generating extra impurity, Zhao et al. reported the full molar ratio design of Co x Fe1− x CO3 (x = 0.2, 0.4, 0.6, or 0.8) by a facile hydrothermal route (Fig. 9c) [175]. Compared with the controlled mixtures of x CoCO3+(1 − x) FeCO3, the single-phase Co x Fe1− x CO3 always demonstrated higher reversible capacity and better rate capabilities (Fig. 9d). By the analyses of differential capacity vs. voltage (dQ/dV) and EIS curves, the superior lithium storage capabilities were attributed to the synergistic effect of the atomic-scale distributed Co, Fe atoms. However, the inner mechanism of the synergistic effect from mixed metal species was still ambiguous. To reveal the uncovered synergistic effects, we further fabricated the single-phase Mn-Co TMCs encapsulated by reduced graphene oxide (Mn x Co1− x CO3/RGO) composites, which demonstrated enhanced electrochemical activity with an ultrahigh capacity of 1454 mAh g−1 after 130 cycles at 100 mA g−1 and ultralong cyclic stability of 901 mAh g−1 after 1500 cycles at 2000 mA g−1 [46]. Combining the theoretical calculation and experimental results, the effect of mixed Co, Mn for enhancing the electrochemical performance could be summarized as follows: (i) formation of porous nano-structure with abundant mesopores induced by the Co-Mn integration in TMCs; (ii) relieving the volume change due to the different reaction positions of Co and Mn ions; (iii) improving the electron conductivity with enhanced electron transportation and redox reaction from the promoted hybridization of O 2p, Co/Mn-3d orbital, as well as the narrower band gap induced by interaction of Co/Mn-3d states; (iv) enhanced structure stability and conductivity from 3D continuous graphene networks (Fig. 9e). Following this study, Ruan et al. discovered that the Mn-Zn binary TMCs also possessed porous structure and high electrical conductivity, which demonstrated the similar synergistic mechanism [58]. After compositing with rGO, the obtained Mn2/3Zn1/3CO3/rGO anode was matched with LiFePO4 cathode to assemble full cells, which shows great potential as the LIBs. Besides the binary TMCs, the single-phase ternary TMCs should also manifest similar synergistic effect to improve the reversible capacity and rate capability. In 2002, Sharma et al. firstly reported the preparation of mixed TMCs of nanosized (Cd1/3Co1/3Zn1/3)CO3 and (Cd0.75Co0.25)CO3, via a precipitation process, which exhibited stable reversible capacities [31]. Li et al. firstly synthesized Mn x Ni y M z CO3 (Marked as S–M, M = Zn, Co ,Cu) ternary TMCs [36]. As revealed in scanning transmission electron microscopy-annular bright field (STEM-ABF), the structural unit was visually observed (Fig. 10 a–d). In a unit rectangle, two partially overlapped O atoms took up the center, C atom occupied on midpoint of the long side, and M atoms located on the vertex, which were marked by green, gray and purple spheres in the STEM-ABF images, respectively. By comparing the Mn x Ni y M z CO3 with different metal atoms, it was found that the O atoms around each M atom was misty for S-Zn, but much more clearly for S-Co and S-Cu, indicating the oxygen vacancies exited in the S-Zn. Moreover, the lattice parameter demonstrated more serious deviations for the S-Zn. These findings were important for the electrochemical conductivity and structural stability for the ternary TMCs. Further, by adjusting different solvent during the solvothermal process, ternary TMCs of Mn0.54Ni0.13Co0.13(CO3)0.8 with multi-shell spherical structure and monodisperse solid spheres were obtained with H2O and EG as the solvent, respectively (Fig. 10e) [176]. The multi-shell spherical Mn0.54Ni0.13Co0.13(CO3)0.8 delivered a high capacity of 806.2 mAh g−1 at 250 mA g−1, showing the great potential of mixed TMCs as LIBs anode. Moreover, the Mn0.54Ni0.13Co0.13(CO3)0.8 were further lithiated with lithium acetate to obtain Li-rich ternary cathode Li(Li0.2Mn0.54Ni0.13Co0.13)O2. The full battery assembled by Mn0.54Ni0.13Co0.13(CO3)0.8 anode and Li(Li0.2Mn0.54Ni0.13Co0.13)O2 cathode showed high capacity of 250 mAh g−1 at the voltage range of 0.1–4 V. Moreover, the synergic effect of the doping metal also reflected in the enhanced stability of TMCs. Tang et al. discovered the inert dopant Ca atom as the framework distributed uniformly throughout the active particles, could efficiently prevent the collapse of active material and further avoid the attenuation of capacity [172]. By comparing the electrochemical performance of MnCO3 fabricated in H2O or ethanal (ETOH), the MnCO3-ETOH demonstrated better cyclic stability and higher capacity, due to the larger square primary nanoparticles with less activity. Inspired by this, the electrochemical inert CaCO3 as the framework was introduced into the system, which can narrow down the scope of collapse, resist the pulverization, and enhance the electrochemical performance (Fig. 10f). (2) Nonmetal elemental-doping Except the metal elemental-doping, the nonmetal elemental-doping has also been studied on the lithium storage properties of TMCs but still at the early stage [177–181]. Liu et al. reported the design and preparation of N-doped MnCO3 [39]. As shown in Fig. 10(g), Mn2+ first combined with NCO2 3− that came from the decomposition of urea to form the MnNCO2 − intermediates, and then the intermediates were hydrolyzed to produce the final N-doped MnCO3. Because N atoms partly substituted the lattice oxygens to generate oxygen vacancy, the final product could be denoted as MnCO(3−1.5 x )N x . Due to the specific structure and physic-chemical property induced by N-doping, the MnCO(3−1.5 x )N x electrode demonstrated improved electronic conductivity and increased electrochemical activity compared with the MnCO3 electrode. Generally speaking, heteroatom-doping is a versatile and effective strategy to optimize the electrochemical performance of TMCs. The main merits of doping on TMCs could be concluded as follows: (i) improving the conductivity with enhanced activation energy for rapid electron transfer; (ii) optimizing the morphology and porosity of the carbonates; (iii) enhancing volume accommodation induced by the porous structure and the different reaction voltage of the components. Therefore, the TMCs with heteroatom-doping exhibited superior electrochemical capacity and rate capabilities to the simple TMCs. Despite these merits, there are also some issues or demerits required to be addressed or noticed. Firstly, the intrinsic insulator/semiconductor characteristic still endow the TMCs with limited electronic conductivity, which induces sluggish electrochemical kinetic. Secondly, although the cyclic stability and the capacity could be enhanced to a certain extent due to the porous structure and synergistic effect induced by heteroatom-doping, the volume expansion still exists for the doped-TMCs, and the long-term cycling stability need be further strengthened. Thirdly, it is still highly desirable to develop more species of the doping heteroatoms and more efficient method to precisely control the doping content and position. The compositing and content of the dopant can directly affect the physic-chemical property of the final products; therefore, the accurate adjustment strategy is important to realize the optimal electrochemical performance. Lastly, the mechanism, especially for the nonmetal dopant should be more explicit. The inner mechanism for the doping strategy can be summarized as the synergistic effect, which reflected in the improved conductivity and enhanced structural stability. Deeper intrinsic influence need be revealed to direct the doping strategy. 5.3 Multifunctional compositing strategy Flagrant issues of TMCs including the instinct poor conductivity and structure degradation have impeded their development. Thus, enhancing the electronic/ionic conductivity and structural stability is definitely the dominating principles for improving the electrochemical performance of TMCs. Constructing multiphase composites by combining TMCs with other components including carbonaceous material, metal compounds and conducting polymer has received tremendous attentions on improving the lithium storage properties of TMCs [182–185]. Thereinto, carbonaceous materials with superfast electron mobility (e.g., ∼15000 cm2 V−1 cm−1 for graphene), high charge carrier mobility (e.g., 20 m2 V−1 cm−1 for graphene) and good mechanical flexibility have been widely used as the conductive additives and structural stabilizer of TMCs [186,187]. Moreover, transition metal compounds are also ideal composite components, due to their polyvalent and multi-morphologies characteristics, which can synergistically optimize the structure and intrinsic property of main ingredients [188,189]. A mass of researches about compositing the TMCs with carbonaceous materials (carbon nanotubes (CNTs) [190,191], carbon nanofibers [192,193] and graphene [194,195], etc.) and transition metal compounds (Fe3O4, SnO2, etc.) [196,197], have been reported and exhibited significantly enhanced electrochemical performance compared with single-phase TMCs. During the charge/discharge process, these materials can (i) provide a bases for the growth of TMCs to modify the structure, in terms of adjusting morphology with more ions transfer path, restricting the agglomeration, and increasing the surface area; (ii) act as an electrical transport path to improve the electron transfer; (iii) enhance the chemo-mechanical stability to guarantee the integrity. Herein, we would summarize the compositing strategy based on the specific affection, in terms of optimizing structure, enhancing electronic conductivity and strengthening chemo-mechanical stability. 5.3.1 Optimizing structure Morphology controlling The carbonaceous materials are often used to modify the electrochemical performance [198–200]. Specially, the graphene, with a unique two-dimensional 2D structure, possesses high specific surface area, and excellent mechanical flexibility, which has attracted enormous interests in energy storage applications [201,202]. During the liquid-phase synthetic process, GO with abundant oxygen-containing groups (–C = O, –C–OH and –COOH) can anchor the metal cations via the electrostatic interaction. Therefore, the micromorphology as well as particle size of the TMCs could be greatly modified. Yao et al. studied the influence of graphene on adjusting the morphology of TMCs [61]. In the absence of graphene, the obtained FeCO3 exhibited hierarchical flower-like microspheres with diameters of 15–30 μm, constructed by numerous radical nanoflakes stretching outwards. These nanoflakes were composed of nanowires building blocks, and assembled into flower-like microspheres to reduce the surface energy. On the other hand, when GO was added into the solution, flower-like FeCO3 microspheres evolved into the 2D nanoflakes fascicled by nanowires that embedded in graphene matrix (Fig. 11 a and b). This kind of morphology transformation was caused by the abundant carboxylic and hydroxyl groups on the surface of GO, which could absorb the positively charged Fe2+ and act as the growing carriers and separators during the hydrothermal process. Moreover, Zhao et al. investigated the morphology evolution of TMCs analogue Co2(OH)2CO3 with the assistance of aspartic acid (AA)-functionalized GO [47]. As shown in Fig. 11(c and d), without adding AA-functionalized GO in the system, the micrometer-sized rhombohedra were synthesized. While in the presence of AA-functionalized GO, the lasagna-like Co2(OH)2CO3 nanosheets were obtained and homogeneously encapsulated in the layer-by-layer self-assembled GO matrixes. The AA linked with GO through nucleophilic substitution reaction of amine groups (–NH2 from AA) and epoxy groups (from GO), and then the Co2+ was tightly absorbed on the GO surface with ample outwards –COOH groups. During this process, the AA could stabilize the Co2(OH)2CO3 nanosheets to prevent their transform to rhombohedra. Simultaneously, the Co2+ induced the self-assemble of AA-functionalized GO (Fig. 11e). This masterly strategy endowed the Co2(OH)2CO3/graphene composites with structural and functional integrality. Moreover, with the coating of MoS2 on the surface of MnCO3, the MnCO3@MoS2 (MCMS) was developed, which was further composited on corroded graphite paper [203]. Due to the novel composition and the morphology, the all-solid state asymmetric alkaline supercapacitor with the MCMS as the negative electrode and NiCo2O4 as positive electrode, delivered high specific energy of 48.97 Wh kg−1 at 600 W kg−1 and capacity retains of 86.5% after 10,000 cycles. The core–shell structures of the MnCO3@MnO2@C spheres [204], MnCO3@MnO2 [205], g-C3N4 quantum dots/MnCO3 on carbon cloth [206], were also obtained and exhibited high energy/power densities. In addition to carbonaceous materials, the transition metal compounds have also been studied to adjust the morphology and microstructure of TMCs. Xia et al. proposed a facile and scalable hydrothermal method to fabricate the binder-free MnCO3/Ni(HCO3)2 composite electrode [208]. During the synthetic processes, the Ni(HCO3)2-MnCO3 hedgehog-like shell@needle first grown on the nickel foam, and then the MnCO3 quantum dots with average size of ca. 1.2 nm uniformly dispersed on the Ni-Mn carbonates substrate, forming the MnCO3 QDs/NiH-Mn-CO3 composite. When directly used as the electrodes without binder and conductive addition, the MnCO3 QDs/NiH-Mn-CO3 demonstrated superior electrochemical performance in terms of high specific capacitance and long-term cycling stability than those for Ni(HCO3)2 on Ni foam. The excellent electrochemical performances were attributed to the following. (i) The novel structure of the composites with high conductive MnCO3 quantum dots and Ni foam bases exhibited higher conductivity; (ii) multi dimension structure with 3D micro-ball composed of 1D NiH-Mn-CO3 nanoneedle and 0D MnCO3 quantum dots, endowed the composites with interconnected pores and high surface area, which could accelerate the electrolyte permeation, and short the ion/electron transfer path; (iii) Ni-Mn composites provided more electrochemical activity with abounded redox reaction sites as well as the synergistical enhanced stability. Dispersibility and size controlling Due to the superb mechanical strengthen and flexibility, the graphene or RGO has also been utilized to anchor and control the particle size of TMCs. With the addition of RGO into the reaction system, the uniformly dispersed FeCO3 particles showed rice-like structure with typical diameter of 50 nm and length of ca. 100 nm, which were embedded on the graphene nanosheets [207]. However, the irregular FeCO3 with larger sizes of ca. 150–250 nm was obtained with severe agglomeration under the absence of RGO (Fig. 11f and g). As shown in Fig. 11(h), due to the smaller particle size of FeCO3 as well as the strong interaction with high electronic conductivity and mechanical strengthen of RGO, the rice-like FeCO3/RGO exhibited superior rate and cyclic performance than pure FeCO3. Moreover, the side length of MnCO3 nanoplatelets was also changed from 3 μm without RGO to ca. 100 nm when tightly anchored onto the RGO, further demonstrating the restrictive effect of graphene [209]. In addition to the homogeneity of the structure, the purity of the components also can be improved. For example, nanosized MnCO3 particles with an average diameter of 8–20 nm were uniformly anchored on the RGO nanosheets (Fig. 11i) [116]. The existence of GO could not only reduce the size of MnCO3 nanoparticles, but also eliminate the generation of Mn3O4 impurity to improve the purity of the final products. In addition to the graphene, the other carbon material also can adjust the structural of TMCs. For example, N-doped carbon dot composed with FeCO3 could change the FeCO3 from the pristine regular nanorods with a length ranging from 200–800 nm to a much smaller nanorods with a size of 40–60 nm [131]. Interface controlling As stated above, the morphology and size control of the TMCs can impact their porosity and interfacial features, which would further determine the electrochemical performance. Zhao et al. designed a special MnCO3 architecture with enhanced interfacial storage capability through compositing with RGO [74]. As shown in Fig. 11(j and k), flower-like MnCO3 with average sizes of 1.2 ± 0.2 μm evolved into petal-like structure with average length of 590 ± 50 nm by adding multifunctional GO into the system. Accompanied with the conversion of morphology and particle size, the specific surface area was also enhanced by sevenfold for the composites than that of pure MnCO3 (28 vs. 4 m2 g−1). Moreover, the porous structures also became plentiful comparing with the flower-like MnCO3 with barely porous characteristics. Due to the superb structural advantages, more “extra” capacities can be obtained from the interfacial pseudocapacitance storage. Composition is an efficient strategy to modify the structure of the transition metal compounds. Due to the abundant functional groups acted as active sites for nucleation and large specific surface to prevent the agglomeration, the composites possess reduced particle size, enhanced interface area as well as abundant porosity architecture. 5.3.2 Enhancing electrons transfer As stated before, one of the most attractive features of carbonaceous material is the super electronic conductivity. For example, the electron mobility of graphene can reach up to 2 × 105 cm2 V−1 S−1, and its charge carrier mobility is 20 m2 V−1 cm−1, 200 times larger than that of Si [210,211]. Therefore, compositing with carbon additives could effectively promote electrons transfer of TMC and enhance the conductivity of the whole electrode [212–214]. The contents and distribution of conductive carbon play critical roles on the final electrochemical performance for composites. Recently, Ruan et al. reported a structure-directing additive free method to fabricate the porous MnCO3 microspheres wrapped by graphene (PMS-G) with different contents of graphene [59]. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurement indicated that the solid electrolyte interface resistances (R SEI) from the fitted Nyquist plots for all the PMS-Gs were similar.
