But the semicircles gradually reduced, indicating that the charge-transfer resistance (R ct) decreased with the increase content of graphene. Remarkably, the graphene in the PMS-G composites could not only improve the Li+/electrons transfer kinetics, but also provide abundant defects to adsorb extra Li+ (Fig. 12 a). The full cells assembled with PMS-G as anode and commercial LiNi0.5Co0.2Mn0.3O2 as cathode delivered a capacity of 107 mAh g−1 and energy density of 144 Wh kg−1, suggesting great potential of TMCs as the next-generation LIBs anodes. In addition, Zhong et al. designed and synthesized the MnCO3/graphene nanocomposites with different graphene sizes [84]. As shown in Fig. 12(b), MnCO3 submicrometer particles were sandwiched into large-area graphene sheets (LG, tens of micrometers in length and width, prepared from the graphite of about 80 mesh size), which joined and interconnected together as whole. On the other hand, when using the small-area graphene sheets (SG, with a fraction of the size for LG, from the graphite of about 3600 mesh size), the MnCO3-SG composites possessed intermittent and irregular structure due to the limited surface. Cross-sectional SEM images further showed that the MnCO3-LG composites constituted with an ordered and contact architecture, but a disordered and loose structure for MnCO3-SG. Therefore, the extended and flat LG nanosheets endowed the composites with parallel electronic conductivity as well as continuous and convenient ions diffusion paths, compared with the discrete and stumbling ion transfer route for the SG. Accordingly, the MnCO3-LG exhibited better electrochemical performance. Except the graphene, other conductive materials, such as CNTs, polypyrrole, also can promote rapid electrons transfer of TMCs [217,218]. The FeCO3/CNT composites with different contents of CNT demonstrated significantly enhanced electronic conductivity and lithium storage capacity [219]. With the H2C2O4 acting as reducing agent and carbon source, the core–shell MnCO3@C composites with cubic MnCO3 core and amorphous carbon shell were obtained [220]. On account of the improved conductivity induced by the carbon material, the MnCO3@C composites possessed superior electrochemical performance. Moreover, Wu et al. reported the fabrication of three-dimensional self-standing MnCO3@graphene/CNT film, in which the MnCO3 nanorods were first encapsulated by graphene sheets and further linked by the penetrating CNTs through vacuum filtration [215]. The features of this novel architecture included: (i) the tight contact between MnCO3, graphene and CNTs to enhance the structural stability; (ii) the interpenetrating intertwined structure with abundant channels to promote the electrolyte penetration; (iii) the multiple dimensions conductive carbon with 2D graphene nanosheets and 1D carbon nanotubes to provide high electrical conductivity. Taking advantages of the multiphase components and delicately designed structure, the MnCO3@graphene/CNT film exhibited super rate performance as Li-ion supercapacitor, as shown in Fig. 12(c and d). Ghosh et al. further investigated the MnCO3/RGO and MnCO3/CNTs composites, simultaneously [221]. Due to the high surface area and outstanding conductivity, both of them exhibited high energy density and power delivery rate, which were in accordance with the other reports [124,222]. Besides conductive materials, some metal compounds have also been introduced to improve the electronic conductivity of the TMCs electrodes. Recent researches showed that the metal boride, especially the Co-B, could not only bridge and anchor active materials to restrain the volume fluctuation, but also act as the electron-conducting bridges to accelerate electron transfer and form interconnected path for Li+ transfer [223,224]. Taking these advantages of Co-B, Li et al. designed a mixed single-phase Mn0.33Co0.67CO3 microspheres with the Co-B compounds covering on the surface (Fig. 12e–g) [216]. In this composite, the Co-B nanoflakes enhanced the mechanical strength of Mn0.33Co0.67CO3 to accommodate the volume change, and promoted the electrical conductivity to increase the rate performance. Therefore, the Mn0.33Co0.67CO3@Co-B composites with multiple synergetic effects demonstrated high capacity, super rate performance, and excellent cycling stability with 806 mAh g−1 over 500 cycles. In addition, the TMOs were also used as the components to improve the electrochemical performance. In our previous report, through a facile and green method, MnCO3/Mn3O4/RGO composites with micro-nano architecture were fabricated [122]. After precipitating the GO/Mn suspension (GO/Mn suspension, including GO, Mn2+, SO4 2− and H+) by Na2CO3 solution, the MnCO3/Mn3O4/RGO were obtained, as shown in Fig. 12(h–k). Compared with the common methods to prepare the Mn-based compounds/RGO composites, our precipitation method not only made full use of the precursor materials, such as Mn2−, CO3 2− and OH−, but also reduced environment pollution by neutralizing the acid solution, and simplified the synthetic technique without high temperature and pressure process. Benefiting from the advantages of the structure and components, the in-situ synthesized MnCO3/Mn3O4/RGO composite possessed higher electrochemical activity and faster kinetics with promoted specific capacity and enhanced stability, compared with the MnCO3/RGO and Mn3O4/RGO binary composites. Except Mn3O4, Fe3O4 also can act as the enhancer to increase the performance. By the exceptional geometry and synergetic effects between the TMC and TMO, the Fe3O4/MnCO3 composite delivered a reversible capacity of 617 mAh g−1 at 100 mA g−1 after 100 cycles, which was much higher than that of pure MnCO3 (287 mAh g−1) and pure Fe3O4 (473 mAh g−1) [225]. 5.3.3 Strengthening chemo-mechanical stability During lithiation/delithiation processes, the electrodes always endure repeated volume expansion and shrink, which results in severe structure collapse and performance degradation. To strengthen the structural stability and cyclic performance, accommodating volume change is pivotal during Li+ ions insertion. Carbonaceous materials with robust mechanical property and flexibility can act as protector and buffer to restrict the active TMCs from volume fluctuation [226–228]. Our group reported a sandwich structured Mn x Co1− x CO3/graphene composites, in which the Mn x Co1− x CO3 particles with average diameter of ca. 1 μm were well encapsulated into wrinkled graphene nanosheets with hundreds of micrometers [46]. As shown in Fig. 13 (a–c), from the top and side views of the composites, the tight contact between Mn x Co1− x CO3 and graphene not only provided continuous electron transfer paths, but also relieved the stress from the volume change to maintain structural integrity. Thus, the as-formed Mn x Co1− x CO3/graphene composites exhibited ultra-long cyclic stability with an ultrahigh capacity over 900 mAh g−1 after 1500 cycles at a high current density of 2000 mA g−1. In addition, Gao et al. proposed a dynamic floating electrodeposition (DFE) method to fabricate graphene wrapped mesoporous MnCO3 [85]. Through this facile DFE process, the GO acted as a flexible cloth to wrap up the deposited MnCO3 particles, and at the same time was reduced to RGO by removing the oxygen-containing groups to finally obtain the MnCO3/RGO architecture. Due to the designed mesoporous structure of MnCO3 and the flexible graphene conductive additive, the integration of the morphology can be retained, and the high capacity also could be reached (Fig. 13d and e). Moreover, Zhao et al. also proposed the MnCO3/RGO composite fabricated by a facile in-situ solvothermal method, which integrated the super electron conductivity and good mechanical flexibility of RGO nanosheets to achieve a long-term cyclic performance [229]. Ding et al. investigated the competition theory by concentrating on the urchin-like CoCO3 dumbbell microspheres and RGO composites [232]. It was found that the pure CoCO3 exhibited rapid capacity decay and gradually increased polarization with cycling going on. This should be due to the relatively weaker effect from the SEI layer than the destructive effect from the repeated Li+ insertion/extraction, finally resulting in continuous collapse of the electrode. While for the CoCO3/RGO composites, the RGO provided overall protective force to relieve the internal structure stress from lithiation/delithiation, which was further reinforced by the SEI layer. Thus, the reversible capacities of the composites maintained stable and the polarization exhibited negligible variation at different current densities, indicating better structural stability, faster Li+/electrons transfer, and electrochemical reaction kinetics. Subsequently, Zhao et al. gave a vivid description of RGO enhanced electrochemical performance of Co2(OH)2CO3 [47]. Compared with pure Co2(OH)2CO3, the composites with RGO not only provided the basement for the formation of Co2(OH)2CO3 nanosheets, but also acted as the electron transfer paths and the barriers to accommodate the volume change. In fact, two antagonistic effects coexist to influence the structural variation of the active materials during charging/discharging processes. On the one hand, the destructive force from volume change of the active material leads to particle pulverization and electrode collapse. On the other hand, the protective force from the SEI layer or carbon matrix, could restrain the electrode deformation and maintain the structural integrity. CNTs and carbon nanofibers (CNFs) with 1D structure, possess linear electrons conducting route and robust mechanical strength [233,234]. Recently, Mn0.875Co0.125CO3@CNFs nanoarchitecture was fabricated through a facile electrospinning method followed by carbonization and hydrothermal processes [230]. For pure Mn0.875Co0.125CO3 particles, the obvious fissuration and collapse were observed due to the hysteresis of volume change for the inner and outside of the active particles, which can induce a sudden interfacial stress and result in the crack. On the other hand, with the CNF network throughout the Mn0.875Co0.125CO3, the as-formed self-supporting Mn0.875Co0.125CO3@CNF electrode delivered dramatically improved cyclic performance due to the enough space to eliminate the structure stress (Fig. 13f). Moreover, the slight expansion of the CNFs in the core could confront the stress from the hysteresis of the shell and core, then reinforcing electrode integrality. Moreover, CNTs has also been regarded as a robust protector to enhance the structural stability. The MnCO3 nanorods homogeneously distributed among retiform multi-wall carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) exhibited super electrochemically cyclic stability, in which the MWCTs effectively buffered the physical aggregation and volume change of MnCO3 [235]. Recently, various metal compounds were also found to be able to enhance the chemo-mechanical stability of TMCs. By constructing the heterojunction-structured MnCO3@NiO composites with porous NiO nanosheets grown on MnCO3 microspheres, the cyclic stability of the MnCO3 raised substantially, mainly attributed to the synergistic effect between the multiple transition metal compounds to effectively improve the electrochemical kinetics, specific surface area, and structural stability (Fig. 13g) [231]. Above all, the favorable hybridization with heterogeneous phases, including carbonaceous material, TMOs, and other metal compounds, is a comprehensive and powerful strategy to optimize the lithium storage properties of TMCs as the following aspects. (i) Optimization of the TMCs with micro-nano structure, uniform distribution and porous features, can enhance the electrochemical activity and promote the electrolyte infiltration; (ii) variable structures of TMC with composite components, such as wrapped, encapsulated, sandwiched, intersected and anchored, increase the integral strength with the enhanced accommodation to the stress; (iii) the addition of conductive materials provides multi-dimensional electron/ion transport/diffusion rout to enhance the electrochemical conductivity and kinetic; (iv) the synergic effect between the components, can effectively enhance the specific capacity and cycling stability. However, some improvements towards the practical application should be noticed. Firstly, the fabrication method should be more facial and induce the cost to ramp up the production. Secondly, the compositing strategy can enhance the comprehensive electrochemical performance, such as the carbonaceous material, but these composites show low tap density, which may decrease the volumetric capacity. To further highlight the advantages of modification strategies on the TMCs, a comprehensive comparison of electrochemical performance has been provided in Table 2 . 6 Summary, challenge and prospect This work summarized the recent advances on TMC anodes for high-performance LIBs, including fundamental electrochemical reaction mechanisms and modification strategies to improve the lithium storage properties. TMC anodes are typical conversion-type electrodes, which react with Li+ to form metal nanoparticles and Li2CO3 during lithiation process. However, the actual reversible capacities are always larger than the theoretical capacity based on the above conversion reaction. Three kinds of reaction mechanisms have been proposed to explain the anomalous capacity. (i) The pseudocapacitive contribution on the electrode/electrolyte interface provides extra charge storage capability; (ii) the chemical valences of metal species change to higher state during oxidation process, and thus the electrode could accommodate more Li+ ions during lithiation process; (iii) the discharge product of Li2CO3 according to typical conversion process could further react with Li+ ions under the catalytic effect of ultrafine metal nanoparticles, thus offering more lithium storage capacity. Similar with other conversion-type anodes, TMCs anodes suffer from low electronic conductivity, sluggish electrochemical reaction kinetics, and huge volume expansion. Guided by the lithiation/delithiation mechanisms of TMCs, various strategies have been developed to modify the electrochemical performance. Firstly, constructing TMCs with hierarchical micro-/nano structure could shorten ions diffusion path and accommodate volume change during Li+ insertion/extraction processes. In this respect, the morphology regulation and the influences of micro-/nano structure on the electrochemical performance are systematically discussed. Secondly, the heteroatom-doping strategy to synthesize single-phase mixed TMCs, in which two or more metal species in one crystal cell, could effectively improve the electronic conductivity and electrochemical activity. Thirdly, constructing composites with TMCs is powerful to achieve excellent electrochemical performance. This modification strategy, involved compositing with conductive carbon materials (such as the graphene, carbon nanotubes, carbon nanofibers), transition metal oxide, and other electrochemically active components, can improve the electrochemical properties. Although, TMCs anodes have received tremendous attentions due to the economic and practical values, which have been lucubrated as promising anodes for next-generation LIBs. However, some inevitable challenges still remain for the TMCs and restrict their further development. Firstly, the electrochemical reaction mechanism about TMCs is still indistinct. (i) The multiple oxidation state change of metal species for extra capacity contribution has only been reported appropriate for Mn-based TMCs, especially the MnCO3/carbon composites. It is insufficient to explain the electrochemical behaviors of other TMCs, and even inadequate for pure MnCO3. Moreover, because the distinct valence change only can be observed in the MnCO3/carbon composites, the impact of carbonaceous materials needs to be discussed and clarified. (ii) The catalytic conversion mechanism indicates that the further decomposition of Li2CO3 product can provide more Li+ storage sites. As a vital part of SEI layer, the repeating decomposition and reformation of Li2CO3 will inevitably lead to the destruction of SEI layer and performance instability. However, the reported TMCs anodes with catalytic conversion mechanism demonstrated good cyclic stability. Therefore, understanding the internal mechanism for the balance of high capacity and cycling stability, including the dynamic process of the growth/decomposition of SEI layers, and the detailed reaction process for the catalyze mechanism, is very pivotal. Due to the significance of the reaction mechanism for developing high-performance TMCs, the in-situ characteristics should be executed, including in-situ XRD, Raman, FT-IR, XPS, HRTEM and XAFS, to explore the valence state and phase transformation accurately during lithiation/delithiation processes. Secondly, the intrinsic deficiency of TMCs, in view of inferior electronic conductivity and ionic-conductivity, severely hinders the electrochemical property, as shown in Table 1. The low charge transfer kinetics of TMC could make severe electrode polarization upon lithiation/delithiation, leading to poor rate capabilities. Furthermore, due to the phase transformation during electrochemical conversion process, the TMCs anodes suffer from large volume variation and structure pulverization upon repeated cycling, leading to rapid capacity attenuation. In addition, the highly active metal nanoparticles formed during the conversion reaction process might induce electrolyte decomposition and some side reactions, thus decreasing the Coulombic efficiency [238]. Although, aiming to address these challenges, the structural establishment combining with the composition design is proved as an effective strategy, the diversity of these method still needs to be expanded and the inner mechanism also need to be clarified. These are essential for long-term work and also the key points for the further research. Overall, the modified TMCs shed light on a way for the eco-friendly, economical and high electrochemical performance, as a new anode material for Li ion batteries. Rui Zhang is a postdoctoral research fellow in College of Materials Science and Engineering, Hunan University. She obtained her Ph.D. in materials science from Harbin Institute and Technology (HIT) in 2019. Her research interests are focused on nanostructured materials for rechargeable lithium-ion and sodium-ion batteries. Qingfeng Fu received his M.S. degree from Hainan University in 2019. He is currently a Ph.D. candidate in the College of Materials Science and Engineering at Hunan University. His research interest focuses on the design, preparation and application of advanced materials for Li/Na/K-ion batteries. Jian-Fang Wu is an assistant professor in College of Materials Science and Engineering, Hunan University. He obtained his Ph.D. in materials science from Huazhong University of Science and Technology (Hust) in 2017. His research focuses on fundamentals of ionic conduction in inorganic materials, materials and battery design for all-solid-state Li, Na and K batteries. Chuanjun Tu is a teacher in the College of Materials Science and Engineering, Hunan University. He received his Ph.D. in materials science and engineering from Hunan University in 2009. His research interests are broadly on the preparation and microstructure control of the structure-function integrated carbon-graphite materials, the modification and application of carbon raw materials, and the relationship among organization structure, property and technology of carbon materials. Jilei Liu is a full professor in College of Materials Science and Engineering, Hunan University. He received his Ph.D. degree in physics & applied physics from NTU, Singapore, in 2015. His research interests include the green production of high-quality carbon allotropes, the sustainable development of high-performance electrochemical energy storage devices (Li/Na/K-ion batteries, alkaline rechargeable batteries, and asymmetric supercapacitors) for renewable energy storage and delivery, and the in-depth understanding of fundamental device electrochemistry. Dr. Liu is a member of International Society of Electrochemistry and The Electrochemical Society. He has authored over 90 refereed and well-cited publications and 1 book.

coredata.dc:description: Even though transition metal carbonates (TMCs, TM = Fe, Mn, Co, Ni etc.), show high theoretical capacities, rich reserves and environmental friendliness as anodes for lithium-ion batteries (LIBs), they suffer from sluggish electronic/ionic conductivities and huge volume variation, which severely deteriorate the rate capacities and cycling performances. Understanding the intrinsic reaction mechanism and further developing ideal TMC-based anode with high specific capacity, excellent rate capabilities, and long-term cycling stability are critical for the practical application of TMCs. In this review, we firstly focus on the fundamental electrochemical energy-storage mechanisms of TMCs, in terms of conversion-reaction process, pseudocapacitance-type charge storage, valence change for charge storage and catalytic conversion mechanisms. Based on the reaction mechanisms, various modification strategies to improve the electrochemical performance of TMCs are summarized, covering: (i) micro-nano structural engineering, in which the influence factors on the morphology are discussed, and multiple architectures are listed; (ii) elemental doping, in which the intrinsic mechanisms of metal/nonmetal elements doping on the electrochemical performance are deeply explored; (iii) multifunctional compositing strategies, in which the specific affections on structure, electronic conductivity and chemo-mechanical stability are summarized. Finally, the key challenges and opportunities to develop high-performance TMCs are discussed and some solutions are also proposed. This timely review sheds light on the path towards achieving cost-effective and safe LIBs with high energy density and long cycling life using TMCs-based anode materials.
